results.title: Simon
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Nargun and the stars”.
A television adaptation of Patricia Wrightson’s novel of the same name, this series is the story of Simon Brent, a 10 year old city boy who is placed in the care of country relatives when his parents are killed in a car crash. Simon finds life very boring until he explores a nearby swamp, where he experiences some odd happenings and finally meets a strange swamp creature called The Potkoorok. From that time on, life is considerably more exciting, mysterious and dangerous for Simon and his relatives, Charlie and Eddie, as they do battle with a menacing giant rock known as The Nargun.

results.title: Simon
results.creator_credit: Hans Casparius, Anne Balfour Fraser and Independent Cine Art
results.brief_description: Simon, a clumsy and slightly backward boy, joins his young playmates in their games in the woods, but is tormented and finally abandoned by them. In this experimental film, the children were given only a rough outline of each scene and themselves improvised the details. The central theme of bullying and group cruelty pinpoints a private purgatory familiar to every child. The beauty of the woodlands where the action takes place symbolises the supposedly innocent natures of children, stressing the disillusioning contrast with their behaviour.

results.title: Simmo, the man I love
results.brief_description: John’s reputation as a great pilot earned him the respect of his colleagues, especially one admirer, Yolanta. But towards the end of his career, it felt like he was losing his touch, something was wrong. Created as part of ‘Memory’s Voice: Capturing Stories of Courage’ in association with Vic Health and the Alzheimer’s Association.

results.title: Simla
results.creator_credit: Chris McCullough and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journey into India”.
Keith Adam recalls the days of the British Raj. He visits Simla, the town in the Himalayas which the British created during the nineteenth century.

results.title: Simba
results.creator_credit: Brian Hurst, Peter de Sarigny and Group Film Productions
results.brief_description: Allan Howard (Dirk Bogarde) arrives in Kenya to join his brother on the farm; tragedy awaits him when he discovers that his brother has been brutally murdered by the nationalistic Mau Mau tribe. He finds solace, and eventually love with neighbour Mary Crawford (Virginia McKenna). Alan works with the local Police Inspector (Donald Sinden), and together they suspect that the local African doctor, known only as Simba, is the leader behind the Mau Mau terrorist attacks. They must now play a tense waiting game. Based on actual events that occurred to British settlers in Kenya in the 1950s.

results.title: Silversmith
results.brief_description: The work of the silversmith is essentially that of a craftsman unassisted by modern methods of mass production. The beauty and delicacy of his hand-made creations in silver and leather make him one of the most versatile of craftsmen. This film shows the many processes involved in the creation of fine silverware, together with the tools which have been used for centuries without change.

results.title: Silvered Water
results.creator_credit: Proaction Film, Les Films d'Ici, Ossama Mohammed and Wiam Bedirxan
results.headline_credit: France, Lebanon, Syrian Arab Republic and United States of America, 2014
results.brief_description: Shot by a reported “1,001 Syrians” according to the filmmakers, Silvered Water impressionistically documents the destruction and atrocities of the civil war through a combination of eye-witness accounts shot on mobile phones and posted to the internet, and footage shot by Bedirxan during the siege of Homs.

constellations_other.name: Cities under siege
constellations_other.description: The Syrian Civil War is an ongoing conflict that is arguably the most documented in history, with images and videos captured by journalists, activists, combatants and victims.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Proaction Film, Les Films d’Ici, Ossama Mohammed and Wiam Bedirxan
results.headline_credit_for_label: France, Lebanon, Syrian Arab Republic and United States of America, 2014
results.description: Shot by a reported “1,001 Syrians” according to the filmmakers, SILVERED WATER, SYRIA SELF-PORTRAIT impressionistically documents the destruction and atrocities of the civil war through a combination of eye-witness accounts shot on mobile phones and posted to the internet, and footage shot by Bedirxan during the siege of Homs. Bedirxan, an elementary school teacher in Homs, had contacted Mohammed online to ask him what he would film, if he was there. Mohammed, working in forced exile in Paris, is tormented by feelings of cowardice as he witnesses the horrors from afar, and the self-reflexive film also chronicles how he is haunted in his dreams by a Syrian boy once shot to death for snatching his camera on the street.
description_for_label: Shot by a reported “1,001 Syrians” according to the filmmakers, SILVERED WATER, SYRIA SELF-PORTRAIT impressionistically documents the destruction and atrocities of the civil war through a combination of eye-witness accounts shot on mobile phones and posted to the internet, and footage shot by Bedirxan during the siege of Homs. Bedirxan, an elementary school teacher in Homs, had contacted Mohammed online to ask him what he would film, if he was there. Mohammed, working in forced exile in Paris, is tormented by feelings of cowardice as he witnesses the horrors from afar, and the self-reflexive film also chronicles how he is haunted in his dreams by a Syrian boy once shot to death for snatching his camera on the street.

results.title: Silverbeat = Silverbeet
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
The 50’s saw a massive intake of young immigrants from Europe, but as these immigrants approach old age the community is encountering problems in how best to cope with their needs, which may be very different from those of the anglo-saxon community to which most retirement and nursing homes are geared. Most of these people come from cultures in which it is not accepted practice to put the aged into institutions. This program looks at two different approaches to the problem - firstly by setting up retirement villages specifically aimed at particular immigrant groups, and secondly by initiating a variety of ethnic foods into the regime of a mixed retirement home.
